hints.content:
Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.

We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

Let's take a look at how Denny broke apart the numbers to multiply.

options.explanation:
$542\times6$

We can break apart $542$ into $500 + 40 + 2$ and multiply each part by $6$.

We can start by multiplying $500\times6$ , $40\times6$, or $2\times6$. The order does not matter since we will be adding all the products together.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&\begin{align}
542&\\
\underline{{} \times 6}\end{align}\\
\text{any order}&\left\{\begin{align}
3{,}000\\
240\\
\underline{{}+12}\end{align}\right.\\
&3{,}252
\end{array}$
options.showPrompt: Can you show me an example please?

hints.content:
###Step $1$

$\begin{align}
3{,}47\blueE{9}&\\
\underline{{} \times \blueE{7}}&\\
\blueE{63}&\quad \blueE{7} \times \blueE{9}
\end{align}$

There are $9$ ones in $3{,}479$, and $\blueE7\times\blueE9=\blueE{63}$. So Denny did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$

$\begin{align}
3{,}4\tealE{7}9&\\
\underline{{} \times ~~~\tealE{7}}&\\
63&\quad {7} \times {9} \\
{{}\tealE{490}}&\quad \tealE{7} \times \tealE{70}
\end{align}$

There are $7$ tens in $3{,}479$, and $\tealE7\times\tealE{70}=\tealE{490}$. So Denny did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$

$\begin{align}
3{,}\maroonE479&\\
\underline{{} \times~~~ \maroonE7}&\\
{63}&\qquad{7\times 9}\\
{490}&\qquad {7} \times 70\\
{{}\maroonE{2{,}800}}&\qquad\maroonE{7\times 400}
\end{align}$

There are $4$ hundreds in $3{,}479$, and $\maroonE{7}\times\maroonE{400}=\maroonE{2{,}800}$. So Denny did not make a mistake in step $3$.

###Step $4$

$\begin{align}
\goldE3{,}479&\\
\underline{{} \times~~~ \goldE7}&\\
{63}&\qquad{7\times 9}\\
{490}&\qquad {7} \times 70\\
{{}{2{,}800}}&\qquad{7\times 400}\\
\underline{+~\goldE{21{,}000}}&\qquad{\goldE{7\times3{,}000}}
\end{align}$

Denny said that $\goldE{7}\times\goldE{3{,}000}$ equals $\goldE{2{,}100}$, so Denny made a make a mistake in step $4$.
Denny made a mistake in step $4$.

question.content:
Denny tried to evaluate $3{,}479\times7$ using partial products, but he made a mistake.  His work is below.

$\begin{align}
&&3{,}479 \\
&&\underline{\times\phantom{22}7} \\
&\blueE{\text{Step 1}}\quad&\blueE{63}&\qquad\blueE{7\times9}\\
&\tealE{\text{Step 2}}&\tealE{{}\phantom{2} 490} &\qquad\tealE{7\times 70}\\
&\maroonE{\text{Step 3}}&\maroonE{\phantom{2}{2{,}800}}&\qquad\maroonE{7\times 400}\\
&\goldE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline\goldE{+\phantom{2}{2{,}100}}&\qquad\goldE{7\times 3{,}000}\\
&\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{5{,}453}& &
 \end{align}$

**Find Denny's mistake.**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: There are $9$ ones in $3{,}479$, and $\blueE7\times\blueE9=\blueE{63}$. So Denny did not make a mistake in step $1$.
There are $7$ tens in $3{,}479$, and $\tealE7\times\tealE{70}=\tealE{490}$. So Denny did not make a mistake in step $2$.
There are $4$ hundreds in $3{,}479$, and $\maroonE{7}\times\maroonE{400}=\maroonE{2{,}800}$. So Denny did not make a mistake in step $3$.
$7\times 3$ thousands $=21{,}000$, not $2{,}100$. So Denny made a mistake in step $4$.
Denny correctly added his four partial products.
